jacs_player

Class AnimatronicsShowPlayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • jacs_player.AnimatronicsShowPlayer

  • public class AnimatronicsShowPlayer
extends Object
    Player for an animatronics show. Allows a user to play an audio file synchronized to Servo motor motions (including specified starting and ending points), a real-time audio feed, and a real time servo feed. An unlimited number of servo motors are supported.

    File input (pre-set motor motions and pre-created audio file) are sent in through an instance of FormattedShowInput, and real-time audio and servo inputs are sent in through the addRecordedAudioInput(byte[]) and addRecordedServoInput(byte, byte[]) methods, respectively.

    Troubleshooting: Note that the servo lag is the lag per motor, so as you add motors, decrease the lag. The basic issue the lag addresses is cutoff of servo motions, so the idea is to have it as high as possible while maintaining the quality of audio playback. Thus, set the lag as high as possible without creating holes in the audio playback. Recommended settings are ~14ms for 2 motors, and decrease from there.
    Author:
    Jared Cline

      • MAX_SHOW_LENGTH

        public static final int MAX_SHOW_LENGTH
        A number denoting the maximum show length in frames. Set to Integer.MAX_VALUE / 3
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        Parameters:

      • playShow

        public void playShow(FormattedShowData data,
            long startTime,
            long endTime)
              throws Exception
        Begins playback of the show specified by the input parameter.
        Parameters:
        data - show data -- see FormattedShowData
        startTime - the number of seconds by which to offset the start of the show from the beginning of the data
        endTime - the number of seconds by which to offset the end of the show from the end of the data
        Throws:
        Exception - if an error is found

      • addRecordedAudioInput

        public boolean addRecordedAudioInput(byte[] input)
                              throws IOException
        Adds the given audio input byte array to the recorded audio input stream for immediate playback. Show input must come in at 44,100 Hz, stereo audio at 16 bits per channel, signed and in big endian format.
        Use the format: AudioFormat format = new AudioFormat(44100, 16, 2, true, true);
        Parameters:
        input - the bytes to be added to the recorded audio input stream
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs writing to the byte stream

      • addRecordedServoInput

        public boolean addRecordedServoInput(byte pinNumber,
                            byte[] input)
        Adds the given servo input for the given pin to the servo output stream for immediate playback. Show input must come in at the same rate as the servo frames per second in the PlayerInputs. I.e. for each recorded motor, the same number of motions (bytes) must come in per second as the show settings. Input is processed immediately (not throttled out), so send input in evenly.
        Parameters:
        input - the bytes to be added to the servo output stream
